H0.text: Protons and Neutrons are both examples of which class of sub-atomic particle that takes its name from the Greek for 'heavy'. Hadron

H1.text: Protons and Neutrons are both examples of which class of sub-atomic particle that takes its name from the Greek for 'heavy'. Lepton

H2.text: Protons and Neutrons are both examples of which class of sub-atomic particle that takes its name from the Greek for 'heavy'. Meson

H3.text: Protons and Neutrons are both examples of which class of sub-atomic particle that takes its name from the Greek for 'heavy'. Baryon

A4.text: Protons and neutrons are examples of baryons, which are composite particles containing three quarks.

A5.text: The name 'baryon', introduced by Abraham Pais, comes from the Greek word for 'heavy' (βαρύς, barýs).
